author: NICK WHIGHAM
title: Badwater 135 ultra marathon 2015: Nikki Wynd wins in Death Valley | The
text:
IT’S regarded as the toughest foot race in the world and an Aussie girl from Melbourne has just conquered it in record time.
“You feel sick,” said Nikki Wynd of her nervous state heading into the daunting challenge. “I hope I can make it,” she recalled thinking.
Known as Badwater 135, the gruelling 217-kilometre race winds its way through Californian valleys and mountain ranges, reaching altitudes of 2500m above sea level where the air is thin and runners struggle to suck in enough oxygen. According to organisers, “it is the most demanding and extreme running race on the planet.”
But that didn’t phase the young Aussie who crossed the line on the early hours of Thursday morning in the US, notching the second fastest time ever recorded by a woman.
“You’ve gotta give it a crack,” she modestly told news.com.au from Lone Pine, California where she is recovering.
At the 70km mark, runners are allowed to be joined by a team member for support. Source: Supplied
Nikki mid race. Source: Supplied
Death Valley California. Picture: Badwater/Adventure Corps Source: Supplied
The starting line is in the aptly named Death Valley National Park in California — it doesn’t get much more foreboding than that.
Kicking off at 11pm on Tuesday night, Ms Wynd said the temperature was still warm. During the day, runners would face temperatures hanging in the mid 40s and despite the blanket of darkness, the heat would barely subside during the night — but it did get “a bit cooler” she admits.
It’s a non-stop race and runners must continuously push ahead. “I had pretty bad blisters,” Ms Wynd said. “I think I spent a total of 15 minutes sitting down tending to them.”
The rest of the time, she had to keep on keepin’ on. “You’re hurting ... and you try to do anything you can to distract yourself from the pain,” she said.
For her, that was thinking about people back home who inspire her. It’s a big deal to travel across the world and undertake this race and she has received a great deal of support from friends and family.
“I didn’t want to let them down,” she said.
The average finishing time for the race is approximately 40 hours and racers face an overall time limit of 48 hours.
When the girl from Lysterfield, Melbourne crossed the finish line in 27 hours, 23 minutes and 27 seconds, she was four kilos lighter. It’s a figure she said was more than desirable, but is almost impossible to avoid.
But on the upside, she was particularly pleased the battery on her iPod shuffle lasted the entirety of the race.
Death valley. Source: Facebook
Runners do what they can to hide from the heat. Source: Facebook
It the second time around Ms Wynd has entered the race — she came third last year. Secure in the knowledge she could complete the imposing course, her strong placing lit a fire underneath the young Australian and this time she went into the event with a personal mission.
Months out from the race, she told her husband she was going to go for the record. “I think he thought I was crazy,” she said. Only half-jokingly.
Even though she had done it before, nothing is a given. “Everything’s gotta go right,” she said. “It’s a weird feeling, you always question yourself”
For Ms Wynd, it was about testing herself in what she called “the pinnacle of ultra marathons”.
“I always like to find the next rush ... it’s about finding the next challenge,” she said.
Which is a good thing because there is no prize money for those who come first. However those runners who complete the intimidating course within the 48 hours receive a prized Badwater belt buckle. Proof of their torture.
You have to work hard for this buckle. Source: Facebook
A hundred people from 23 countries competed in this year’s event, 29 of them were women.
Pete Kostelnick from the US won the men’s race with the best over all time of 23 hours and 27 minutes.
As for Ms Wynd, she’s going to have a week of well-earned relaxation in California before making the triumphant journey home.
Nikki Wynd of Australia, first place female, second fastest female time ever, broke Pam Reed's 40+ record!
Posted by Badwater on Thursday, 30 July 2015 Originally published as Meet the toughest woman in Australia
